text: hi I'm Sarah when I first tried this

her Tia's no matter what they were
filled with now for the enchiladas you
need to begin by making a sauce so I
have about a tablespoon of canola oil
right here in this pan I'm adding one
small onion finely chop a clove of
finely chopped garlic and pepper I use a
whole jalapeno here and I use the seeds
but if you would like to and you want a
milder flavor just remove these seeds
before you chop them up like I said I
like it spicy so I've left all of mine
in the thing about jalapenos is they
really vary in spiciness you're probably
gonna want to taste them and if they're
really sensitive wear gloves because
they might not want to get that on your
skin a quarter of a teaspoon of chili
powder adds a little bit of flavor to
this sauce cook these until the onions
are translucent over medium heat that'll
take about oh eight minutes to that one
can a 28 ounce can of whole tomatoes in
puree and about 1/2 a cup of water I
like to do it right into the into the
can and swirl it around to get up all
the remaining stuff from the can of
tomatoes just add that in season it with
salt and pepper generously bring to a
boil reduce the heat and simmer crushing
the tomatoes with the back of the spoon
until the tomatoes are tender and broken
down and the sauce is slightly thickened
that'll take about 15 or 20 minutes
meanwhile I'm gonna heat up some of

make sure it has enough seasoning it's

bit of pepper now to form the enchiladas
I've already made a few you're gonna

eight tortillas 12 ounces of cooked
shredded chicken
this can be leftover chicken roasted

of chicken inside each tortilla some
Monterey Jack cheese 12 ounces

but if your kids or anybody in your

they'll take about five to seven minutes
the
should just be bubbling and melted on
